issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to a 'Milkable' interface (with method messageOnMilk()), but the solution repository introduces a differently named interface 'Dairy' and has classes (Goat, Seal) implement Dairy instead of Milkable. Additionally, Milkable.java in the solution repository is empty/missing. This naming/type mismatch between 'Milkable' and 'Dairy' is a structural inconsistency that will confuse students and cause compilation problems (code referring to Milkable cannot be satisfied by a Dairy interface).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the interface name and type consistent across all artifacts. Replace or rename the 'Dairy' interface in the solution to 'Milkable' (with the signature String messageOnMilk()), and have Seal and Goat implement Milkable. Alternatively, add a proper Milkable interface and remove/alias Dairy so that code referencing Milkable (as described in the problem and present in the template Main) compiles and matches the specification.

issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to an interface named 'Milkable' (and require implementing messageOnMilk()), but the solution repository defines and uses an interface named 'Dairy' for the same concept. This renaming (Milkable <-> Dairy) is an unintended identifier inconsistency: students reading the exercise will look for/implement 'Milkable' while the reference solution and some solution classes use 'Dairy', which breaks direct mapping between requirement and implementation and may confuse students or cause automated checks to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the interface name across all artifacts. Rename the solution's 'Dairy' interface to 'Milkable' (update Dairy.java -> Milkable.java and change 'implements Dairy' to 'implements Milkable' in Goat.java and Seal.java), or alternatively rename references in the problem/template to 'Dairy'. Ensure there is a single interface file named Milkable with the method messageOnMilk() so students can directly map the requirement to the implementation.
